thread.title: Misbehaving student, 7, got PTSD after school stuck her in 'scream room,' $300k suit says
thread.title_full: Misbehaving student, 7, got PTSD after school stuck her in 'scream room,' $300k suit says | OregonLive.com

author: Aimee Green | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Misbehaving student, 7, got PTSD after school stuck her in 'scream room,' $300k suit says
text:
Riverbend Elementary School Springfield Public Schools The family of a 7-year-old developmentally disabled student who says she was stuck in a dark, windowless "scream room" by her teacher has filed a $300,000 lawsuit against Springfield Public Schools.
The girl suffers from claustrophobia, post traumatic stress disorder, nightmares and fear of darkness because of repeated forced visits to the 6-by-8-foot room, says the lawsuit filed Thursday in Lane County Circuit Court. The room was used to punish her, the suit says.
A representative from the school district couldn't offer immediate comment Friday.
Seclusion rooms are allowed under Oregon law, with restrictions. But in 2013, state lawmakers banned school districts from locking students in free-standing "seclusion cells," which critics had likened to containers designed to traumatize students. The bill didn't prohibit educators from placing students in rooms that some say help calm out-of-control students.
The girl attended Riverbend Elementary School and had been diagnosed with "multiple developmental disabilities," the suit says.
On Jan. 26, 2012, a court-appointed special advocate arrived at the school unannounced to visit her and was told by a teacher that the girl was "napping," according to the suit. When questioned further, the teacher said the girl had a "meltdown," the suit states. The teacher then led the advocate to the student.
The advocate "discovered her lying in a fetal position on a bare concrete floor in an approximately 8'x6' cold concrete room, with only thin carpet on the floor and no apparent padding or heat," the suit says. "The room had no ventilation or windows and ... (the girl) was alone in the dark, without a pillow, mattress, chair, or any other furniture whatsoever."
Because of public controversy over seclusion rooms, new state rules that took effect in July 2014 established more specific requirements -- including that the walls of seclusion rooms are at least seven feet apart and that the rooms have lighting, ventilation and a window in the door that allows the entire room to be viewed.
According to the lawsuit, the teacher told the advocate that school district policy calls for placing misbehaving students in such "scream rooms." Parents aren't told that their children have been put in the rooms, and the district doesn't or didn't keep records on using the rooms, the suit says.
A mental health professional and a caseworker had been assigned to the girl through the Oregon Department of Human Services, the suit says. Neither of them -- nor her mother -- were told that she'd been placed in the small room, the suit states.
The girl's mother has since died, and her maternal grandfather, as her guardian, filed the suit on the girl's behalf. The suit claims that her time in the room worsened her problems -- magnifying her Oppositional Defiance Disorder, among other problems.
The suit claims that use of the seclusion room was "an extraordinary transgression of the bounds of socially tolerable conduct."
The family seeks $25,000 in economic damages and $275,000 for the girl's trauma and suffering. She is now 10.
The lawsuit was filed by Salem attorney William Ghiorso.
Seclusion rooms are used by various districts around the state. For example, a Beaverton School District spokeswoman said the district has five seclusion rooms, and they all meet state specifications.
